message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main component of pulmonary surfactant is phospholipids, specifically dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC). This phospholipid reduces surface tension in the alveoli and prevents them from collapsing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main component of pulmonary surfactant produced by type II pneumocytes are phospholipids, specifically phosphatidylcholine. This reduces surface tension in the alveoli and prevents alveolar collapse. Protein S and surfactant-associated proteins are also involved in surfactant function, but they do not make up the main component. Zinc finger proteins are not directly involved in surfactant production or function.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pulmonary surfactant, produced by type II pneumocytes, is composed mainly of phospholipids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main component of pulmonary surfactant produced by type II pneumocytes is phospholipids. While there are other components, such as protein S and surfactant-associated proteins, phospholipids make up the majority of pulmonary surfactant and are crucial in reducing surface tension in the lungs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pulmonary surfactant is made up of phospholipids, along with surfactant-associated proteins and other minor components. However, phospholipids are the main component produced by type II pneumocytes and are essential for reducing surface tension in the lungs and preventing lung collapse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main component of pulmonary surfactant is phospholipids, which reduce surface tension in the alveoli and prevent their collapse. Protein S, zinc finger protein, and surfactant-associated proteins are also present but not the main component.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main component of pulmonary surfactant produced by type II pneumocytes is phospholipids, which help reduce surface tension in the alveoli and prevent collapse. While surfactant-associated proteins are also important in the function of surfactant, they are not the main component.

The main component of pulmonary surfactant produced by type II pneumocytes is phospholipids, which reduce surface tension and prevent alveolar collapse. Protein S and surfactant-associated proteins are also present but are not the main component. Zinc finger proteins are not involved in pulmonary surfactant production.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main component of pulmonary surfactant produced by type II pneumocytes is phospholipids. Surfactant-associated proteins are also important but are not the main component. Protein S and zinc finger protein are not directly related to pulmonary surfactant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main component of pulmonary surfactant produced by type II pneumocytes is phospholipids, specifically dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC). Other components include surfactant-associated proteins (SAPs) and protein S, but phospholipids are the main component that reduces surface tension in the alveoli and prevents collapse during expiration.
